resource.string: A prudent ruler allows for times of shortage in all things, even the simplest.
The salmon of wisdom calls to fishermen.
Grain feeds the city; well fed men do their betters' bidding.
Legionaries must be housed and trained, so that they may stand in harm's way.
Earliest of spectator sports, wrestling is an ancient tradition.
Zeus Ammon is widely revered by Greeks and Egyptians.
Horus, bringer of the dawn and of wisdom, gives much to the people.
An established village, growing by hard toil and devout effort.
Let lesser people, not Romans, build in wood.
All who seek honour in battle should honour Andraste.
For great rulers death is a reminder of greatness.
Those who hope for strong sons honour Fraujaz.
Joy and love, truth and justice: all are celebrated.
With careful planning water brings abundance.
Hephaistos is patron of smithing and sculpture, and men do well to honour his works.
Honouring Mars brings a martial spirit to the city.
Praise be to Zeus Ammon, father of Alexander.
Regular practice and training conditions both riders and horses for war.
There is an art to skirmishing that requires practice.
Give honour to Imhotep, wisest of the wise, and healer of healers!
The wisdom of Epona is shared with those who do her honour.
From tiny acorns great oaks grow.
Blacksmiths forged the ancient world, in bronze, iron and steel.
Merchants and trade flourish where Melqart is honoured.
Egyptians and Greeks can worship Serapis in equality.
To bend water to our will is a great power indeed.
The fire god Hephaistos helps those workers who honour him.
A shining centre of politics, religion and trade for the people.
Pay your respects to all the gods and they shall all bless you in return.
The worship of Imhotep, Brother of Thoth, is a righteous path to wisdom and healing.
A shrine to Melqart, the god of trade and the underworld.
Once dried and salted, fish can be traded far and wide.
Fear the might of the fire god dwelling in the heart of the volcano.
What cannot be bought is not worth buying.
Tuotatis offers his protection to those who honour him.
Animals require large areas of land to be given over for their care.
Water is life, and it pays to guard it as you would a life.
Sea legs can be found when there is glory and gold to be gained.
The man who can read sees beyond the horizon.
Expertise comes only with diligent practice.
The home of the fleet, where mastery of the sea is planned.
Many voices raised as one: the voice of the people.
Serapis will help those who honour him properly.
The Great Provider watches over the faithful.
This mighty temple to Neptune ensures that all enterprises at sea go well.
Is there anything more exciting than a day at the races?
Cavalry require serious training to attack and manoeuvre on the field.
Whipped with rods, burned by fire, and taught to handle the blade.
Armour is not cowardice. Every stroke turned aside weakens the foe.
A gateway to the world, the colonies, and to trade and war's terrors.
Destiny is shaped by breeze and branch.
Safe haven from pirates and storms, and a place to trade.
Born or sold into service, the plight of slaves remained the same.
Pens. For cattle.
Poseidon rules the deeps, shakes the earth, and is master of horses. No sensible man ignores him.
The god of smiths should be honoured by all honest toiling folk.
All praise to Hathor of love and motherhood, and Maat, weigher of the soul.
A well trained horse is worth its weight in cattle.
When food is plentiful there is money to be made in cattle.
The gods need a place to call their own.
All a man could want is within.
Knowledge and philosophy feed the soul.
The voices of the gods are heard more clearly in the open air.
For settlers and traders, towns are home to opportunities undreamt of in villages.
A strong tribe deserves a strong home.
A great colonnade, where grain merchants can ply their trade.
If it walks upon four legs, the discerning gourmand can find it here.
For most people, a village is the whole world.
Noble horses are fitting mounts for the best of cavalrymen.
Full of life and opportunity, the greatest city forever reinvents itself.
A centre of trade, politics and military power, bringing glory to a people.
The forges turn out arms and armour in great number.
Managing water is vital for survival during droughts and sieges.
A beacon in the darkness, bringing light and order to the world.
A doorway beyond the mortal realm, and home to nymphs and lesser gods…
Many hands make light work.
Small towns breed ambitious men.
Through his knowledge the smiths make weapons to protect our people.
Worship the goddess if you would have success on the battlefield or in the bedroom!
The basilica properly honours Jupiter and makes clear the virtue of Roman good order.
Inspiration comes to those who honour Wodanaz.
Ships from far lands bring necessities and luxuries to trade.
Weapon practice for soldiers is essential if oaths are to be fulfilled.
The Auxiliaries are the second fist of the Roman Empire, and vital to its wars.
When all is recorded and remembered, society can be organised.
Argument and debate may grow heated, but in that fire knowledge is forged.
A live calf may not last the winter. A smoked one will.
Sacrifice to Ba'al, and await his blessings.
Astarte is goddess of war and love, but not necessarily at the same time!
The rising sun and light of dawn bring renewal every day.
A herd provides more than food.
The city is the heart of a people, where culture and learning flourish.
Drydocks enable speedy production of even the greatest warships.
Constant practice makes every shot deadly on the battlefield.
The dead wait, and the living should remember them.
The proper sacrifice will gain the god's favour when the red mist of war comes.
Thought must be tested, and sometimes found wanting, by considered debate.
Non-citizens must be properly organised if they are to serve Rome effectively.
Improving the land always improves the harvest.
From the bowels of the earth come these glittering treasures.
All honour to the daughter of Jupiter, and to her wisdom in all matters!
A city riots without bread, but it dies without water.
A place to meet, chat and share a sponge…
Citizens, subject troops, conscripts and levies muster here for drill and war.
A shrine to honoured ancestors and rulers, and a reminder of history.
A place of bones, where the dead return to the elements.
The bones of the ancestors should be properly reverenced.
The gods favour men who can craft wood and iron to cunning purpose.
A good harvest can bring many rewards.
A safeguard of history and philosophy through the ages.
Andraste watches over our warriors and keeps them safe in times of war.
Honouring Mercury brings the god's favour to merchants and their works.
Brave riders do well when they honour the Lady Epona.
The potter's art is a valuable one.
Ancestors should be treated with proper veneration.
Thunaraz! Bringer of plenty and protector of the people!
Farms and small estates provide for the the majority of the people.
Ale is not a solitary pursuit!
The 'Horned One' blesses the endeavours of those who work the land.
If you eat or drink almost anything, the chances are it came from an amphora.
Where land does not allow farming, ranching is the best option.
There are places where the gods once walked.
Nodens brings forth the bounty of the forests.
Slaves from across the world are bought and sold: meat to the grinder.
Harbours provide and promote trade, whilst giving shelter from pirates and storms.
Oases of calm, offering divine protection, these groves of sacred trees symbolised nature.
This circular dockyard houses the fleet and its righteous commander.
Within the timber is a ship waiting to be born.
Feathers, fur or claws: all can be purchased…
An army needs weapons as well as warm bodies.
Fish, to different degrees of freshness, can feed a whole city.
Glory in defeat sometimes surpasses mere victory.
A little banter and trade is profitable to all.
Poseidon, the god of the seas, looks askance at those who do not honour him.
A shining city, a seat of power and a source of pride…
Underground channels can securely carry water vast distances.
Any fool can throw. Practice means that the fool might hit home.
Salt goods are highly valued by men from the south.
Allies and mercenary troops must be mustered and brought to order.
The honoured youth of Carthage should be given proper burial.
The rich bounty of the sea can feed many people.
The games honour the gods, and the victors!
Athena, patron of courage and wisdom, is rightly celebrated in bronze.
The great maw of the people must be fed from great estates.
Teiwaz! War is his domain, blood his sustance.
Does anything speak more eloquently of wealth and good taste than a fountain in a courtyard?
Protector of women in childbirth and blesser of marriages!
Hastily-erected camps familiarise levied citizens or subjects with the ways of war.
A game of war, masquerading as a noble sport.
Out of sight, out of mind, but vital to civilized living…
With prosperity comes growth and greater prestige, both religious and political.
Riches grow when people work together.
Every shot practiced is an enemy life taken.
Well-fired bricks and tiles speed building works.
Salted or dried fish can be sent far beyond the ports in which they were landed.
An empire is built one brick at a time.
Give praise to Horus the Elder, guide and giver of wisdom to dread Pharaoh!
Social and athletic pursuits allow men to measure their worth.
Honour the lord with grandeur and see his blessings rain down!
A Greek slave is not just a strong back, but a good mind too.
There is more to war than swinging a sword, or carrying a spear.
Forged in fire, carried in battle, honoured in victory.
The Gods will have their vantage point.
Well equipped docks enable the construction of great fleets.
A warrior comes home with his shield, or on it.
Ships built and outfitted for war need a home port.
Hic!
Settle, take what you need, and move on.
Tuotatis keeps the women in warriors' beds and wolves from the gates!
The essential container for transporting all food and drink.
The army that builds, conquers.
Cattle are the basis of Carthage's strong agricultural economy.
Even in death, power is a statement to the people.
A civilisation measures itelf by culture.
We must gather the fruits of the field.
To gain a little you must give much and travel far.
Local administration, governing a community and its surrounding network.
The strength of Fraujaz is in the seed of those who worship him.
The worship of the mother goddess, beloved of her people, brings bounty to the settlement.
The world is hammered into shape on many forges.
The city is the heart of the Carthaginian people, their religion and trade.
The strength of iron makes fine weapons.
A soldier needs more than skill with the blade. The shovel is important too.
Men able to afford and stable horses still need training in the arts of war.
The finest battle steeds require special attention.
A full belly is most welcome in the depths of winter.
Strong arms need strong weapons.
Fleet horses outpace and outmanoeuvre the enemy.
The wisdom of the kings and their advisors must be preserved for all.
Arrows do not shoot themselves, nor rocks hurl themselves at the enemy.
A wise man watches for wolves in the wilds, and fires in the city.
Water increases crop production, and improves the soil.
A book copied is a civilization strengthened.
Horsemanship and status are intertwined; the common man walks.
In the stone heart of the city an oasis is always welcome.
Through song and poetry the glorious dead are honoured.
Fire destroys but it can also create.
Tanit is consort of Ba'al, and the mother of Carthagians.
The easiest way of keeping meat fresh is to keep it alive.
A thriving community with trade to attract new settlers.
The protection of the gods always has a price.
Tread carefully all who enter here.
The creature that does not wander is safe.
Water, in abundance, brings joy as well as life.
Here are the answers to many questions for those who listen, and respect the trees…
Many beautiful items can be made from simple clay.
The Great Mother blesses her followers according to their worth.
Sensible care of valuable animals saves much effort and money.
Honouring Vulcan brings his favour to smiths and craftsmen.
Much of what is wrong with life can be cured by good wine.
Nothing enriches the land quite as well as a master’s eye.
The land breeds men fit for the fight: strong of arm and will.
The knowledge of the gods will be revealed to the true of heart.
Where warships gather, and armies embark for conquest and spoils.
The wealthy and the elite are entitled to their perfect gardens.
Trade is the life's blood of an empire, even more than military might.
With great power comes great responsibity.
Only a fool goes to sea without the blessings of Poseidon, lord of the deeps.
The purity of fire warms the spirit and the heart.
A growing town reflects the prosperity and loyalty of a province.
Great engines of war are crafted from strong oaks.
Amphorae are needed in huge numbers to carry goods across the world.
The world is carried on backs sold to the highest bidder.
A permanent garrison gives the safety needed for growth and trade.
Austro! As bright as the dawn; as beautiful as spring!
The downfall of every empire begins here.
A domed storage building, cooled by water evaporation.
Fish are always good, but fish sauce is more welcome still to a good Roman!
Bricks and mortar last longer than political ambitions.
Behold the god of war marches before us!
Serapis, god of Egyptians and Greeks, gives his blessings to all equally.
The spice must flow.
The Thunderer should be properly honoured by all mortal men.
Great herds of sheep, goats and cattle drive out simple farmers.
Skill with bow, sling or javelin comes only through constant practice.
Lady Frijjo, beauty of the gods and protector of the home!
Teiwaz strengthens the hearts of the brave and true.
Cunning and forethought can breach enemy walls.
The humble farmer carries everyone on his back.
Honour, by your devotions, the goddesses Hathor and Maat.
Beyond the grandeur, the Roman world is one of villages not great cities.
Music and poetry should have a home in a civilized city.
The beauty of gold is more than its worth.
Where levied citizens and subjects muster, and train to become soldiers.
Those wanting success in war would do well to honour Ares.
The city is the heart of a people, birthing place of civilisation and culture.
The bounty of Neptune's depths feeds both gourmets and gutter-trash.
Drill should be a bloodless battle.
A colonia, no matter how small, is a new Rome rendered in bricks and mortar.
Hail Wodanaz! Bringer of knowledge and wisdom!
Heart of Hellenic cities, the Agora was a place of politics, religion and trade.
A bustling centre of trade moving goods from east and west.
The Mother of All, the blessed Isis, protects and nurtures her true followers.
The satrap speaks in the king's voice; lesser men listen carefully.
The dead must not sully earth, fire or water.
Exotic spices and wonders from afar bring wealth and marvels!
The skill of the carpenter puts roofs over our heads.
Clever water use allows great gardens to flourish with the right care.
When ships can find safe haven, the people will prosper.
Within the grove the worlds of gods and men are as one.
Raise a horn to the gods! And be thankful!
A drydock aids the construction and maintenance of any battle fleet.
A little salt is useful, a lot is profitable.
Fine dining and good drinking are welcome accomplishments of civilization.
All good plays are dedicated to the gods.
Communities thrive and grow on common ground and interests.
The camp is home to proper soldiers, not a comfortable garrison.
A well is the gift of Ba'al Hammon, and should be treasured above even gold.
Life-giving water: always a welcome thing.
A small community founded for common goals and in shared beliefs.
Give all praise to Imhotep, for his learning and wisdom.
Which is more important: grain for the bakeries, or sand for the arena?
Even as her followers honour her, the tears of Isis fill the Nile.
Successful villages attract trade and settlers, and grow as a result.
A centre of administration, religion and trade.
Command of the sea requires a powerful navy.
As the city and its appetites grow, so do the unfortunate end results.
A shrine to Isis, goddesses of magic and nature, and mother of the people.
An artistic eye can be useful and profitable.
Taming the waters is a noble goal.
A prosperous centre for trade and commerce full of opportunity for the right people.
Give thanks: honour the goddess for the coming of Spring.
Belief and faith bring a people together in common cause.
Commerce fuels growth and wealth for a community and its people.
Without trade, the people cannot flourish and enjoy prosperity.
Precious water for all the community.
Slavery was common practice and traders could be found in every town.
Organising levies requires planning and space.
Spice, medicine and incense are prized throughout the world.
Wise words are worth hearing, even if wisdom is unpalatable.
Skill in battle is useless without endurance and determination.
There is blood and glory on the sands, for all men to see.
The game is one thing, winning quite another.
Fraujaz! Bringer of fertility and lord of the marriage bed!
Hard lessons are best learned before war's clarion blast is heard.
The Pharaoh provides for all the worshippers of his land.
The rich bounty of the sea can feed a people.
Honour the Maiden, and ensure the renewal of Spring.
Learning to make every shot count requires diligent practice.
The spirits know much and will speak to the devout.
Merchants from across the world trade goods and gossip.
All the world can be bought or sold on these wharves.
The sea-road leads to the wider world.
Water is the bringer of life and must be respected.
Fire and crime must be guarded against at all times.
He who commands the sea goes where he wills, and fights where he wills.
Those who are not awed are certainly very dead or very stupid.
An army must be gathered and organised before it is sent on campaign.
The crafty arts and many devices of Hephaistos are worthy of praise.
Herald of the gods, Hermes should be honoured for the messages he brings.
People are often made happy by a small thing: an absence of dung.
An underground chamber, cooled by the flow of wind and water.
Austro, bringer of spring and its wonder, is honoured by the wise.
There is one business here: war, and the ships needed to wage it.
If soldiers fight mock battles and sieges reality will not unman them.
Great estates centralise ownership, bringing vast areas under the control of a few.
In all the hubbub, the world is there for a handful of gold.
The golden and beloved rulers of all must be protected.
The rule of law allows trade to flourish, even at sea.
Iron is to be honoured and respected.
Zeus, the god of all the Hellenes, ruler of Olympus, requires proper worship by his followers.
Without amphorae, what of the wine?
Fish is always a welcome meal on any table.
A library is the memory of an entire people.
The God of War grants victory to those who do him honour.
When many hands work in concert, there are few limits to what can be done.
No great man with interests willingly forgoes a trip to the baths.
Not all land is suitable for arable farming.
Soldiers use shovels as often as swords, assuming they want to win.
No wall is impregnable if a man thinks long and hard, and possesses the right tools.
The appetites of the people must be fed.
Permanent quarters can lead to better equipped, trained levies.
Purify, and seek healing from the god Eshmun…
Fountains are beautiful, practical and above all very, very civilised.
Wise commanders have their men practice both siege defence and assault.
Revere Zeus, the master of Olympus, before all other gods!
Amphorae are everywhere, and used to store almost everything.
%placeholder%
Permanence brings opportunity and challenge.
Stern-faced Mars should be suitably honoured by a warlike people.
Authority sees much from the saddle that is missed from a lowlier viewpoint.
The corn exchange sets the price of food, and of starvation.
Some men are born free, but not all die that way.
Praise the swift god of trade!
"""We will make them fear the seas!"""
The legion is a finely tuned machine for making war anywhere at any time.
If we take care of the land, it will take care of us.
Eshmun is the god of healing and renewal, and worthy of praise.
Pray to the daughter of Jupiter, that she will guide you through life’s challenges.
Small communities thrive through shared endeavour.
Through his knowledge of the Otherworld he creates power from the earth itself.
Soldiers must be separated from civilians, and imbued with discipline.
It's more than racing: supporting a team is life, death and eternal loyalty for the fans…
A shrine to the lord of storms and bringer of the rains.
No honest Roman city should lack a temple to Jupiter, the bringer of order…
Lady Epona: guardian of all noble steeds.
Power is a curious thing: it must be seen to be believed.
Together, we are stronger.
For those seeking healing and protection what better places is there?
The sacred flame holds back the night and disorder.
There is nothing more Roman than cleanliness and gossip in the baths.
Command of the seas comes from Carthage's great fleet.
Any fool can swing a sword. A gladiator is taught to fight well and to die well.
Honest toil in the fields is rewarded by Cernunnos.
Those who honour Ba'al Zephon are protected from hunger.
Jupiter, King of the Gods, watches over all men and judges their acts.
Pilgrims and traders come to receive Melqart's blessings and aid.
Coins mean less bloodletting come market day.
The daughter of Zeus, patron goddess of Athens, is worshipped for her courage and wisdom.
Slaves are the sinews of an empire. Nothing can be achieved without them.
More than just a marketplace, the forum is the hub of all society.
An honest wine merchant is always happy to drink his own wares.
A fountain is an echo of the ever-changing tranquility of Olympus.
A tribe that drinks together, stays together!
Minerva helps those who listen to her wisdom, and do her proper honour.
The gods provide the bounty of the oceans.
Even in death, royalty have power.
Children are the blessings and joy of Frijjo.
All warriors should honour mighty Teiwaz.
A tower that cunningly channels the breeze to cool a building's occupants.
When the merchant goes to so much trouble, isn't it rude not to drink his wares?
All the world is in a city, a stroll from your front door.
The noble horse has much to teach us.
As an archive and centre of learning, nothing rivals the Great Library.
One measure of wine is good, so how much better ten thousand?
Wherever there is a town, there is the Roman world.
Where would a Roman be without the finer things in life to adorn his dinner table?
Much can be learnt about a man from his bulls.
Goods from the furthest reaches come to many shores.
All generals look to siege weapons to break the enemy's will.
Only Kore's initiates understand. It has to be that way.
Zeus Ammon, the father of Alexander the Great, looks after his faithful followers.
If something cannot be bought or sold here, no one wants it!
Nobility should buy its privileges with unflinching service in war.
Large scale sun drying needs entire fields, not just brickyards.
Cattle and oxen must be held somewhere before slaughter.
There are princes among horses.
Athena grants wisdom, military strategy, and courage in battle to the faithful.
Water is the lifeblood of the land, moving unseen.
Those who honour Nodens will never go hungrey.
Rosmerta provides for the weary traveller.
Simple clay makes greatness possible.
Skill can be passed on, but what of the master's feel for bow, breeze, and arrow?
The Muses guide the hands and thoughts of those who look for beauty and wisdom.
A port is a gateway to the world of trade and military adventure.
The armourer is remembered every time a blow is turned aside.
The wing-footed messenger of the gods should be given his due honours.
Drilled and disciplined, soldiers are only as good as their training.
The depths of the earth are a safe place to store food.
The village is the heart of the people.
Trade and war both demand the right animals.
The demand for meat can be met by turning over land to cattle.
Cunning makes many things, both beautiful and dangerous.
The old mysteries should never be ignored.
A little common ground is vital in any settlement.
Strength in battle does not come without effort and sacrifice.
Swift horses for light cavalry to harry and chase the enemy.
A warrior needs a weapon he can rely on.
From the depths of the earth comes life giving water.
Captives are the spoils of war.
A fresh catch gets a good price in town and city.
Hermes protects those who travel afar, and those athletes who run quickly!
Animals are prized for their milk, hides and wool as well as their meat.
The training and quartering of elite troops requires the proper surroundings.
Those who honour Austro do not fear harsh winter.
Gobannus, lord of fire and iron, is honoured by all who need metal.
Battle is the test of quality.
Those who work the fields would do well to honour Thunaraz.
Honour the god of the sky, and accept Ba'al's blessings in return.
Neptune, God of the Sea, helps all sailors who properly honour him.
The landlubber finds sea legs in the same place as gold and glory.
The trees provide much for those who know their secrets.
A good death met with dignity shows the virtues of a proper Roman life.
Skilled metalsmiths make the deadliest weapons.
Grapes grow everywhere, but wine flows only where it is bought.
Inns, or pandocheion, cater to the needs of weary travellers.
Many, particularly traders and thieves, should ask Hermes for his protection.
The mighty ocean provides more than fish.
From abundance comes wealth.
All should give deserved praise to the Evening Star.
Ba'al's shrines are open to the sky, and do him honour.
All water flows from Neptune, especially when he is given due deference.
Stout walls keep out many unwanted visitors.
A clever chieftain does what is best for his people.
There is simple Roman honesty in a farm.
A swift arrow brings joy to Nodens heart!
Fine wines always command a high price.
These buildings allow the spear drill training of citizens or subjects.
Water is always welcome, particularly when rains do not come or an enemy does.
Conscripts and levies are drilled in mock battle so that they understand something of real war.
It is a great dishonour to abandon your shield and run…
Professional mercenaries can supplement the ranks of citizen soldiers.
At the heart of a settlement is law, trade, and paperwork.
Many nets are better than one.
If you cannot buy it, you did not really want to eat it in the first place.
Providing water and a place to bathe is a worthy thing.
Egypt's great harbours are renowned for their engineering and as centres of trade.
The warrior goddess thrives on the blood of enemies!
Thunaraz rains his blessings on those who pay tribute to him.
Exercise strengthens raw recruits, both physically and mentally.
If you go down to the woods today…
The city is the home of civilization, culture, comfort and pleasure.
The voices of the gods are always clear in the open air.
The greatest inns are always found on well-travelled routes.
Control the memory of past, and you control the present and future.
There is nothing more welcome at the end of a day's travel than a comfortable inn.
Many hungry mouths are filled in a town.
Citizens must have somewhere to gather and drill before battle.
Heavy horses, bred for stamina and strength as heavy cavalry mounts.
A warrior cannot ride a sheep into battle!
Home to all manner of exotic beasts.
A rough sea is no place to keep a valuable vessel.
Honouring Cernunnos ensures a bountiful harvest.
The fleet headquarters is both symbolic and practical seapower.
Sun drying bricks and tiles needs space.
If the wealthy buy education it will be of more use than more wine…
Skilled artisans make the world, and the weapons to conquer it.
The rich enjoy luxuries paid for in blood.
Kilns allow the mass production of tough, fired bricks.
Traditional, sun-dried bricks are a common building material throughout the Hellenic world.
A well-tended field produces superior crops.
A good general wants engines of war to rain down devastation on his foes.
Where warships gather and troops embark for conquest.
